text: Page 1
label: BODY

text: Headings in Documents
label: H1

text: I ntroduction
label: H1

text: Headings are vital for accessibility because they provide structure, helping users navigate the
label: BODY

text: document easily. They enable screen readers to identify sections, allowing efficient jumps to
label: BODY

text: specific content. Headings also give context to topics, enhancing comprehension. Properly
label: BODY

text: formatted headings improve visual organization, benefiting all users, including those with
label: BODY

text: cognitive disabilities. Overall, using headings significantly enhances document accessibility and
label: BODY

text: usability.
label: BODY

text: T able of C ontents
label: H1

text: Full Accessibility Check - Newer Versions of Adobe ........................................................6
label: BODY

text: Full Accessibility Check Older Versions of Adobe Acrobat.................................................8
label: BODY

text: Revised 1/17/2025
label: BODY

text: Page 2
label: BODY

text: S etting U p the D ocument P roperties
label: H1

text: There are three parts to setting the basic document properites:
label: BODY

text: Setting the Document Title
label: BODY

text: Setting PDF Metadata to Use the Document Title
label: BODY

text: Setting the Language in PDF
label: H2

text: Performing these steps first when opening any PDF document will help resolve the most
label: BODY

text: common errors before you start the remediation process.
label: BODY

text: D ocument T itle
label: BODY

text: Setting the Document Title
label: BODY

text: First check if the document has a document title. If it doesn’t add the title. If the source
label: BODY

text: document (such as Word, Excel, or PowerPoint) includes a title, the PDF will typically carry it
label: BODY

text: over. Otherwise, you will need to add a title to the PDF. Follow the steps below to determine if
label: BODY

text: the document title has been set properly .
label: BODY

text: Older Versions of Adobe Acrobat
label: H3

text: Click on “File” at the top of the menu bar.
label: BODY

text: Select “Properties” to open the Document Properties window.
label: BODY

text: Page 3
label: BODY

text: Newer Versions of Adobe Acrobat
label: H3

text: Click on “Menu” at the top left of the window.
label: BODY

text: Select “Document Properties” to open the Document Properties window.
label: BODY

text: View the Description tab to determine if the document has a title and/or if the title is an
label: BODY

text: appropriate description of the document. If the title is accurate, proceed to next section. If
label: BODY

text: the title is not there or is not accurate, proceed to step 4.
label: BODY

text: Note: Steps 3 and 4 are the same in both older and newer versions of Adobe Acrobat
label: BODY

text: If there is no title, or if the title does not provide an accurate description of the document
label: BODY

text: click in the Title field and select any text in it. Type in the new accurate document title.
label: BODY

text: Page 4
label: BODY

text: S etting PDF M etadata to U se the D ocument T itle
label: H2

text: When adding a title to the document, the metadata must be updated to reflect the new
label: BODY

text: document title instead of the file name.
label: BODY

text: Note: These steps are the same in both older and newer versions of Adobe Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Make sure you are still in the Document Properties. See last section for guidance.
label: BODY

text: Click on the “Initial View” tab.
label: BODY

text: If the “Show” dropdown menu is set to “File Name” change this to “Document Title”
label: BODY

text: Page 5
label: BODY

text: S etting the L anguage in PDF
label: H2

text: Screen reader technology will read the document to the user in the language set for the document.
label: BODY

text: A document can only have one language setting. The steps to set the correct language in a PDF
label: BODY

text: are:
label: BODY

text: Note: These steps are the same in both older and newer versions of Adobe Acrobat.
label: BODY

text: Click on the “Advanced” tab in the Document Properties window.
label: BODY

text: Choose the “Language dropdown” and change it to the correct language. In this case
label: BODY

text: “English.”
label: BODY

text: Click the “OK button to save any changes to the PDF title or language.
label: BODY

text: Page 6
label: BODY

text: F ull A ccessibility C heck on D ocument
label: H1

text: F ull A ccessibility C heck - N ewer V ersions of A dobe
label: H2

text: The first step is to conduct a comprehensive (full) Accessibility Check to identify any errors
label: BODY

text: that need to be addressed in the Content Tool in the All Tools Menu on the left. This menu is
label: BODY

text: displayed by default on the left side of the page.
label: BODY

text: Locate the All Tools menu on the left and click the Prepare for accessibility button.
label: BODY

text: Click on Check for accessibility
label: BODY

text: Page 7
label: BODY

text: Verify that the Category drop-down is set to “Forms, Tables and Lists”.
label: BODY

text: In the Accessibility Checker Options dialog box, under Checking Options, verify that it
label: BODY

text: shows (32 of 32 in all categories). Then click on Start Checking.
label: BODY

text: The Accessibility Checker panel will appear on the right side of the document. Expand the
label: BODY

text: arrows to see the accessibility issues.
label: BODY

text: Page 8
label: BODY

text: F ull A ccessibility C heck O lder V ersions of A dobe A crobat
label: H2

text: The first step is to conduct a comprehensive (full) Accessibility Check to identify any errors that
label: BODY

text: need to be addressed in the Content Tool on the left tool menu.
label: BODY

text: Use the Accessibility Tool on the right side of the document tool menu.
label: BODY

text: Select the Accessibility Check tool in the Accessibility tool to see if there are any errors.
label: BODY

text: Page 9
label: BODY

text: Verify that the Category drop-down is set to “Forms, Tables and Lists”.
label: BODY

text: In the Accessibility Checker Options dialog box, under Checking Options, verify that it
label: BODY

text: shows (32 of 32 in all categories). Then click on Start Checking.
label: BODY

text: The Accessibility Checker panel will appear on the left side of the document. Expand the
label: BODY

text: arrows to see the accessibility issues.
label: BODY

text: Page 10
label: BODY

text: H eadings
label: H1

text: L evel 1 H eadings
label: H2

text: Using a heading level 1 (H1) is essential for accessibility as it establishes a clear document
label: BODY

text: hierarchy, indicating the main topic or title of the document. This helps users, especially those
label: BODY

text: using screen readers, understand the layout and flow of content. Setting an H1 gives users
label: BODY

text: immediate context about the content, making it easier to grasp the purpose of the document at
label: BODY

text: a glance.
label: BODY

text: Please note that the Accessibility Checker may not always detect if a document is
label: BODY

text: missing a level 1 heading, but it is essential for every document to include one.
label: BODY

text: This is a manual review item, as automated checks cannot identify all accessibility
label: BODY

text: issues; some must be assessed by a person. If your document does not have a level 1
label: BODY

text: heading, identify one at the top of the first page.
label: BODY

text: To add a Level 1 Heading to a page:
label: BODY

text: Click on “Prepare for accessibility” or Accessibility depending on the version of adobe you
label: BODY

text: are using.
label: BODY

text: Newer Versions of Adobe Acrobat
label: BODY

text: Appears on the left side of the screen
label: BODY

text: Older Versions of Adobe
label: BODY

text: Appears on the left side of the screen
label: BODY

text: Page 11
label: BODY

text: Select the Reading Order tool
label: BODY

text: Newer Versions of Adobe Acrobat
label: BODY

text: Older Versions of Adobe Acrobat
label: BODY

text: Page 12
label: BODY

text: In the Reading Order dialog box make sure that Structure types are selected. This will
label: BODY

text: allow you to see the structure of the document.
label: BODY

text: Page 13
label: BODY

text: Right-click the text that should be the level 1 heading and choose “Tag as heading 1” from
label: BODY

text: the pop-up menu.
label: BODY

text: Run full accessibility check to see if issue has been resolved.
label: BODY

text: L evel 2 H eadings
label: H2

text: For longer documents, adding level 2 headings provides key benefits for accessibility and
label: BODY

text: usability. They create clear sub-sections, helping users understand the information hierarchy.
label: BODY

text: Screen readers can easily identify these headings, allowing efficient navigation. Level 2
label: BODY

text: headings break content into manageable sections, enhancing comprehension and retention.
label: BODY

text: They also improve visual layout, making it easier for all users, including those with cognitive
label: BODY

text: disabilities, to follow the content. Consistent heading structures promote better readability and
label: BODY

text: accessibility.
label: BODY

text: To add a Level 2 Heading to a page:
label: BODY

text: Click on “Prepare for accessibility”
label: BODY

text: Select the Reading Order tool
label: BODY

text: Page 14
label: BODY

text: In the Reading Order dialog box make sure that Structure types are selected. This will
label: BODY

text: allow you to see the structure of the document.
label: BODY

text: Page 15
label: BODY

text: Right-click the text that should be the level 1 heading and choose “Tag as heading 1” from
label: BODY

text: the pop-up menu.
label: BODY

text: Run full accessibility check to see if issue has been resolved.
label: BODY

text: L evel 3-6 H eadings
label: H2

text: Adding level 3 to level 6 headings is not recommended due to accessibility challenges. Too
label: BODY

text: many heading levels can complicate the document structure, making navigation harder. Some
label: BODY

text: screen readers may misinterpret these headings, causing confusion. Additionally, excessive
label: BODY

text: levels can clutter the layout, hindering focus, especially for users with cognitive disabilities.
label: BODY

text: Inconsistent use of headings can disrupt the reading experience. To enhance accessibility, it’s
label: BODY

text: best to limit heading levels to 1 and 2 for clarity and effective navigation.
label: BODY

text: Page 16
label: BODY

text: I ncorrect H eading I ssues
label: H2

text: Cause of Incorrect Heading Issues
label: BODY

text: This is often caused by heading levels being used out of order, formatted without the correct
label: BODY

text: styles leading to a lack of or confusion about the content structural hierarchy.
label: BODY

text: Examples of Incorrect Headings
label: BODY

text: The examples below illustrate a level <H3> heading used immediately after a level <H1>
label: BODY

text: heading, without an intervening level <H2> heading, and a level <H4> heading following a
label: BODY

text: level <H2> heading, without a level <H3> heading in between. Headings must follow a proper
label: BODY

text: order, which is often the source of these issues. To meet ADA requirements, headings cannot be
label: BODY

text: used out of order.
label: BODY

text: Page 17
label: BODY

text: Fixing Incorrect Heading Issues
label: H2

text: To fix this problem, change the structure of the element:
label: BODY

text: Right-click on the element under the Appropriate Nesting – Failed message and choose
label: BODY

text: “Show in Tags Panel” from the drop-down menu. This will highlight the problem element in
label: BODY

text: the tags panel.
label: BODY

text: Page 18
label: BODY

text: Review the content of the tag and its surrounding elements to determine if the tag should
label: BODY

text:
be changed to a paragraph

tag, or if another type would be more appropriate.
label: BODY

text: In this case, the word “Important” should not be a heading, so we would change it to a
label: BODY

text: tag by following the steps below.
label: BODY

text: a.	 Right-click the element’s tag and choose Properties from the pop-up menu
label: BODY

text: Page 19
label: BODY

text:
b. Change the tag to a

tag by clicking on the Type field drop-down menu and select
label: BODY

text: the appropriate tag from the list. Then click the close button.
label: BODY

text: Perform a complete accessibility check to determine if the issue has been resolved. Please
label: BODY

text: note that fixing one issue can sometimes result in the total number of issues remaining
label: BODY

text: the same or even increasing, as this may disrupt the order of other elements. Continue
label: BODY

text: addressing each issue until the total decreases and remember to run a full accessibility
label: BODY

text: check after each fix.
label: BODY
